column2: The happy and well-entrenched custom of visiting people's places in the country over Summer weekends is now at the very zenith, and this column undertakes a round-up of gifts for guests to take to their hosts and hostesses. A present that is a little out of the ordinary--the ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--An Administration drive to line up the Senate votes needed to pass the Burke-Wadsworth Compulsory Military Service Bill was begun today, but so much opposition was shown that some supporters predicted a compromise would be necessary.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity advanced again in the week ended July 27, despite losses in four of the seven components. It reached 101.7, compared with 101.1 for the previous week and 91.5 for the week ended July 29, 1939.

Recovered from the illness which kept him in Flushing Hospital for a month, Ken Strong, former New York University star, will be among those who will report at the New York Football Giants' training camp on Aug. 15.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 3--A beehive of activity this morning, Fort Dix is virtually deserted tonight with the departure of 3,000 members of the Citizens' Military Training Corps, reserve officers and regular Army troops.

WHEN anxious days that try the soul are hard upon us and we tally up our strength and weakness, we tend to overlook re sources that cannot fly or float, cannot become bombs or bayonets. We tend to forget that America is a land of lakes and woods and streams which nurtured a people strong enough to tame a continent. Those resources, too, deserve a place in the tally.

The rapid development of new materials and construction methods has created the need for a restudy of the building codes of the country with a view toward the adoption of basic codes that would be applicable not only to individual States but which might be extended beyond their boundary lines, a report of the committee on structural service of the American Institute of Architects declares.

PAYMENT: American holders of Norwegian Government bonds learned last week that August interest and sinking-fund payments would be met. The assurance came from Wilhelm Morgenstierne, Minister to the United States of the Norwegian Governmentin-exile. Interest payments totaled $1,040,420.

More than 85 per cent of the mobile forces of the Regular Army and National Guard within the continental United States were moving toward five different manoeuvre areas last night or were ready for departure from home stations today or tomorrow.

LONDON, Aug. 3--In the opening days of last week a fair demand for loans was experienced because of month-end considerations, but as a result of subsequent heavy treasury bill maturities, the position again has become distinctively easier. Fresh loans are obtainable at to 1 per cent.

Some interesting facts regarding variations in realty values in different sections of Manhattan are presented by the Real Estate Board of New York in its latest survey of sales conditions. The present study involves a comparison of values for the first six months of this year as compared with same periods in 1938 and 1939.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 3 (AP)-- The First Grand Circuit meeting in Rhode Island in thirty-three years closed at Narragansett Park today with a nine-heat card of minor events. Most of the leading stables already had shipped their star trotters and pacers to Goshen.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3--Conditions created by the war have had a pronounced effect on the American gift industry, it was revealed in a survey of the Gift Show and China, Glass and Pottery Market, which got under way this week at the Merchandise Mart.

WITH the recent signing of the new basic agreement between the Metropolitan Opera Association and the American Guild of Musical Artists the forms of contract previously in use and many of the practices about which the artists complained have been abolished by mutual consent.

LAKE PLACID-A quiz program will be a feature of the Red Cross benefit to be held in Agora Theatre at the Lake Placid Club on Tuesday evening.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 3--The firing opened today in the Eastern grass court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club, but it hardly was loud enough to be heard across the street. Of the sixteen home-bred seeded players in the tournament only one saw action.

HOLLYWOOD. IN Hollywood today the centuries live close together. The Florence of Savonarola may be separated from the Paris of Bonaparte by a twenty-minute walk, slender minarets of ancient Baghdad may cast their shadows across antebellum Vienna, in the studio commissary Charlemagne may lunch tvith Florence Nightingale.

DETROIT-Automobile production slumped to the lowest level this year during the past week, with the Ford Motor Company the only large passenger car plant in production. Chevrolet closed its lines on Friday to begin work on its 1941 series.

SIX years on a Vermont homestead have not dimmed the luster of the Van de Waters's adventure in coun try living. Nor have two previous books setting forth its charm and interest exhausted the literary possibilities of the subject, as this new book conclusively proves.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 3-- The Rumanian Government's discussions with thirty-six prominent Transylvanian leaders has caused much agitation among political circles here.

As the week's sales of cotton goods were estimated at two and a half to three times production, buying by consumers exceeded the pressure of hedging operations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and, as a result, prices gained 1 to 5 points.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--The War Department reported today awards of contracts totaling $17,704,403 for aircraft weapons, automotive equipment and anti-aircraft and other defense materials.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4 (AP)--Putting on one of the great "stretch" finishes for which he long has been famed, Ralph Guldahl of Chicago shot a final round of 67 today to win the $5,000 Milwaukee open golf championship with a 72-hole total of 268 strokes, 16 under par for the North Hills course.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--Attorney General Robert H. Jackson warned today that the Justice Department would not accept such a plan for "avoiding the limitations of the Hatch act" as that proposed yesterday by Henry P. Fletcher, counsel to the Republican National Committee, for subdividing campaign contributions.
VICHY, Aug. 4--The organization of the occupied zone is taking place rapidly, so far as the public administration is concerned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)--Up in Buffalo, N.Y., one of the nation's most important aircraft production centers, government and industry have collaborated in the construction of what is probably the world's fastest single-engine interceptor pursuit plane.

MADRID, Aug. 4--Spain's war debt to Italy has been funded at 5,000,000,000 pesetas, it was disclosed today in an official summary of the national financial position. Under an agreement reached yesterday, Spain is to repay the debt over a twenty-five-year period beginning Dec. 31, 1942.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The Republican National Committee announced today that Representative Dudley A. White of Ohio had bean named director of the speakers' division with headquarters in Chicago.

Most divisions of the New York wholesale market reported good activity last week. Interest in Summer merchandise was unusually protracted, due to the hot spell and heavy orders arrived on cheaper dresses, cottons, beach and sports wear and men's promotional Summer goods.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 (AP)--The Red Sox checked the Tigers today, 7 to 3, with Old Lefty Grove the master of the Bengals, just as he has been for sixteen years. The Boston victory cut the Detroit lead to a half game. It was Grove's fifty-ninth triumph over Detroit, which has beaten him only sixteen times.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)--The Athletics beat the Senators, 6 to 4, today with a splurge of doubles in the ninth and tenth innings. With Philadelphia trailing by a run in the ninth, Catcher Frank Hayes batting in a pinch-hitter's spot, doubled home Bennie McCoy to tie up the game at 4--4.

The Williamsburgh Savings Bank sold to a client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., the two five-story apartment houses at 113-17 Debevoise Street, Brooklyn, for cash above a mortgage of $55,000 held by the seller, which has been extended for five years.

Bank clearings this week rose 16.7 per cent over the corresponding period last year and substantial gains were recorded both in and outside New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)--The Department of Agriculture forecast this year's cotton crop today as 11,429,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, based on Aug. 1 crop conditions. Production last year was 11,817,000 bales and the average in the ten years 1929-38 was 13,547,000 bales.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8--John Hay Whitney had his best 1940 day at the races when two of his horses won here today, Wait for Baby capturing the featured Molly Brant Handicap, and another ran second, just losing in a nose finish.

A fine collection now being shown at Nettie Rosenstein's awaits release to the stores. It is a beautifully designed array of style trends, clothes evolved in the best New York-Paris tradition.

LONDON, Aug. 8 (UP)--Great Britain never will surrender a single ship to Germany, a high British naval spokesman promised today in supporting a plea that the United States lose no time in selling fifty to 100 destroyers to this Country.

A further sharp contraction in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System is reported for the week ended on Wednesday. The latest cut is $180,000,000, reducing the total to $6,330,000,000, the lowest since the week ended on May 15.
Hearings on the proposed excessprofits tax are scheduled to start today at Washington in joint sessions of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee.

The report of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation for the first half of 1940, announced yesterday by Guy W. Vaughan, disclosed a consolidated net profit of $6,236,969 after depreciation, interest, reserves and taxes at the current rates. In the 1939 period the profit was $3,370,804.

NAPOLEON never gave rubber a thought. It was only a curiosity to him. Shoes were his great problem, because his armies marched. But Hitler? Rubber is a military necessity today. His armies did little marching. They rolled along at twenty, even forty, miles an hour on rubber-tired motor cycles, in rubber-tired motor trucks or flew as parachutists in planes with rubber-tired undercarriages. A blitzkrieg without rubber is simply inconceivable.

THE Columbia Recording Corporation took a drastic step in its price policy last week. Through its president, Ed ward Wallerstein, it announced a sweeping reduction of its records in the field of serious music. A masterwork set will thus cost $1 a record with the usual addition of 50 cents for the album.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11--Corn prices averaged somewhat higher last week, but the issuance of a government report showing a prospective yield of only 2,248,000,000 bushels, the smallest, with four exceptions, in thirty years, and compared with 2,619,000,000 bushels in 1939, fell flat as a market influence.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 11-- Blown by a fine easterly breeze of fourteen knots part of the way, and a haul to south southeast to a diminishing strength of six knots, the fleet on the fourth and last run of the American Yacht Club cruise came over here today from Gardiners Bay, in the jaw of Long Island.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP)--Recapturing a berth in the first division, the Pirates trounced Chicago 7-3 and 5-1 in both games of a doubleheader today to give the Corsairs three of the four-game series.

LAFAYETTE, La., Aug. 11--Six thousand refugees from Louisiana's flooded rice bowl were established today in hastily improvised quarters beyond the edge of the flood as typhoid and diptheria epidemics threatened.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11--Issuance of the official Aug. 1 crop reports on the United States and Canadian wheat last week afford statisticians material with which to make what is regarded as a fairly accurate forecast as to the amount of grain available for the current crop year.

About 500 attacking planes were said to have taken part.

Washington reports indicate that the full strength of the opposition to the Military Service Bill will be shown on the Maloney amendment.

Joe Cronin's somewhat jaded Red Sox made a despairing bid at the Stadium yesterday to puncture the Yankees' suddenly inspired dash to retrieve their lost fortunes before it is too late to retrieve anything.

Sales of heavy electrical equipment spurted sharply in June to new highs for the year and to levels the best since mid-1937, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

The candidacy of James Blaine Walker Jr. as the Republican organization designee for Congress in the Eighteenth Congressional District was formally announced yesterday at the Manhattan Willkie Campaign Committee headquarters, 17 East Forty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--Expansion of Naval Reserve aviation training programs to handle a maximum of 1,600 men a month was announced today by Secretary Knox.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--Loss of overseas trade by Italy was the principal economic factor in the first month of that country's participation in the European war, James W. Young, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, reported today in a general summary of foreign trade data.

A further settling process took place yesterday in the stock market as the character of trading reverted to the listless pattern of July.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP)--Shot Put, a 4-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. Marie Evans, set a North American record, for two miles and six furlongs by winning the $2,500 Lucien Lyne Handicap at Washington Park today. Cheick Rama was second, ten lengths back, with Temulac third. The time was 4:48 4-5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)-- Charging that registration rolls had been "padded" in Jersey City, home of Mayor Frank Hague, James A. Tumulty Jr., independent candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey, requested today an investigation by the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee.

Total advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities, measured by Media Records, declined 1.1 per cent in July, chiefly because the month had only four Sundays as against five in the like month of last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18--Technological advance in the implements of war is so rapid in the United States, officials said today, that the government is able to release each week for foreign sale twelve to fifteen devices formerly considered military secrets.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18--The New Jersey Federation of Labor, spokesman for some 250,000 members, endorsed today the candidacy of President Roosevelt for a third term.

DETROIT, Sept. 18--Industry need have no fear that its plants and facilities will be drafted under the present conscription bill, Robert P. Patterson, assistant secretary of war, told the National Industrial Advertisers' convention here today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18--Jessie Reed, once one of the highest paid show girls in the world, died today, a charity patient at the Chicago Osteopathic Hospital. She was 43 years old.

One of the largest fleets of British bombers thus far used carried out a vigorous counterattack against the German threat of invasion Tuesday night and yesterday. One group attacked French, Belgian and Netherland coastal points, while

BERLIN, Sept. 18--German "armed reconnaissance planes" took off this morning to view the effects of last night's raids on London. According to the official news agency, D.N.B., "in individual districts of East London entire residential sections [Haeuserviertel] that stood there yesterday had disappeared."

A group of American opera singers and musicians headed by Nino Martini and Helen Jepson will sail for Puerto Rico on Saturday on the liner Cherokee for an operatic visit. The company, known as the National Opera Company, will give seven operas in the auditorium of the University of Puerto Rico in San Juan.

In slightly more active trading, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 2 points lower to 3 points higher. Strength was centered in the near months, largely reflecting buying by a spot house. The absence of heavy hedging operations is a strengthening factor.

Bringing to a climax a family quarrel over the sale of real estate, Joseph De Grieco, 64 years old, a barber, of 401 West 127th Street, shot and seriously wounded yesterday his brother-in-law, John Sinibaldi, 56, who occupies a separate apartment at the same address.

LONDON, Sept. 18--Nothing is known today on which to base comment on reports that the Germans have shelled this capital from the coast of France, whose nearest point is Calais, about a hundred miles away.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18--President Roosevelt signed today and thereby made into a law the Wheeler-Lea bill which will combine all regulation of interstate commerce, except air traffic, within the Interstate Commerce Commission. The principal effect of the new law is to transfer jurisdiction over inland waterways from the Maritime Commission to the I.C.C.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 18 (AP) --A Harrisburg theatre closed today after running for matinee audiences the picture "The Ramparts We Watch," containing a reel barred by the Pennsylvania Board of Censors as "part of the fear propaganda being disseminated by Germany."

ROME, Sept. 18--The taking of Sidi Barrani, officially announced by the Italian High Command today, has marked the end of the first stage of Italy's campaign in Egypt, according to military circles here. Marshal Rodolfo Graziani has been busy for the last forty-eight hours

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 18--The University of Pennsylvania is celebrating its bicentennial this year and of paramount import to the undergraduates in the success of the festivities is the fortune that awaits the football team in process of development in the training camp here.
LONDON, Sept. 18--The House of Commons went into an urgent secret session tonight on the problems created by aerial bombardment of London. Only the briefest of communiques was issued afteward.
A duplex apartment of eleven rooms in the cooperative building at 823 Park Avenue has been leased by Dana C. Backus, attorney, through Frances E. Deverell, broker.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18--The best Christmas toy business since 1929 is the expectation of wholesale tenants in the Merchandise Mart, a survey revealed today. Percentage increases in sales currently are running 20 to 75 per cent ahead of 1939, Percy Wilson, managing director of the mart and vice president of Marshall Field Co., said.

Moved by the suffering continual air raids are causing the British people, fourteen American religious leaders joined yesterday in asking their co-religionists in this country to observe Sept. 29 as a day of national prayer to be known as Great Britain Sunday.
Following are the candidates of the Democratic and Republican parties, selected at Tuesday's primary election (*Signifies incumbent):

A greater percentage of the population of New York, New Jersey and Delaware will be conscripted than in all but possibly one of the nine other corps areas as a result of the comparatively poor recruiting records made here in the last year, it was estimated yesterday by local recruiting officers.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18--Professor Louis F. Fieser, Harvard chemist who last year synthesized Vitamin K, the blood-clotting vitamin which prevents hemorrhage, reported today before the bicentennial conference of the University of Pennsylvania that experiments

Mrs. Rogers H. Bacon of 55 East Fifty-eighth Street, long well known for her activities in social service and education, died Monday in Montreal while returning with her husband from a fishing trip in the Laurentian Mountains.

Resumption of the covering movement on cotton gray goods, following about ten days of relatively quiet trading, resulted yesterday in sales of print-cloth yarn goods in volume equal to about a week's current production. Other gray and

Old Tom Delaney--"Old Tom" purely from affection, since he was only 62--died before noon yesterday in Bellevue Hospital, where he had served thirty-five years as lamplighter, messenger and late-trick receptionist. He had put in more years of service than any member of the hospital staff.

R. G. Le Tourneau, Inc., makers of road machinery, announced yesterday a net profit of $1,603,909 for the first eight months of this year. This is after depreciation, Federal income taxes based on the 1940 Revenue Act, and other deductions, but before provision for excess profits tax. The earnings equal $3.56 a

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 (AP)--The Republicans, who could muster only 126,034 votes six years ago and ran third to the Progressives and Democrats, pushed into a wide lead in total ballots cast in yesterday's Wisconsin primary.
Having shown South America what a group of talented young American musicians can do, the AllAmerican Youth Orchestra returned to regale the home folks. They and

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18 (AP)-- Horse racing in New Orleans, where it had been a sport more than a hundred years, died today with the sale of the Fair Grounds track for $460,000 to a realty group that will convert the property into a residential section.
The Canadian dollar recovered 62 points to 83.62 cents in the freemarket here yesterday, due to a decline in offerings rather than to an appreciable increase in the demand. The Canadian rate, how

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey had ten police lieutenants and detectives questioned at his office yesterday in an investigation of wholesale vandalism in the preceding twelve days by a gang of thugs he suspects is in the hire of labor union leaders. It was esti

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 18--The surf caster has much in common with the waterfowl hunter, especially on the matter of weather. When the wind is lifeless, the sun bright and the water mirrorsmooth, both the surf caster and the duck hunter gather up their duffle and head for home. But

Spokesmen for business and civic groups, department stores, organized labor and the sign industry, appeared at a public hearing of the City Planning Commission yesterday and voiced their approval of the commission's proposal to create in the "Times Square area" and

READING, Pa., Sept. 18--Ignoring threats by the State Board of Motion Picture Censors to close his theatre and confiscate the "Ramparts We Watch" film, put on the screen at its Pennsylvania premiere here today. Cornelius G. Keeney, manager of the Park Theatre, went ahead with the presentation of the picture.

Yesterday afternoon Macy's offered a choicely selected fashion show against the crisp new decorations of its Little Shops, from which smart corner of this store the new clothes were taken. The silver background of the deep showcases and the pink tint of the walls proved an ideal setting for the sophisticated presentation.

LONDON, Sept. 18--In the fitful moonlight outside one of London's subway stations, closed during air raid, a young woman in the neatly tailored blue uniform of the London Transport Organization stands nightly calmly directing would-be passengers to the nearest raid shelter.

The second anniversary of "Hellzapoppin," which began its eventful career here on Sept. 22, 1938, will be observed a bit prematurely this evening at the Winter Garden with a series of special doings. Many Mayors, here for their annual convention, will attend and Mayor La Guardia will take part in the proceedings. There will also
Now that "Johnny Belinda" has reached the stage, there may not be enough drama left to last through the rest of the season. Elmer Harris has shot the works in one evening at the Belasco Theatre. The

LONDON, Sept. 18--One of the largest forces of British bombers thus far used in the war, this morning and last night further hampered any German preparations for sending land troops against Great Britain's gates.

Big Babe Phelps hit the jackpot in the first inning, a mighty drive into Bedford Avenue sending the Dodgers off to a 4-0 lead over the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday, but the same Dodgers hit bottom later in the afternoon. With

VICHY, France, Sept. 18--The public prosecutor especially assigned to the Supreme Court at Riom has requested the indictment of former Premier Edouard Daladier and General Maurice Gustave Gamelin, the former Commander in Chief.

LONDON, Sept. 18--The British really are beginning to get tough. A few days ago the government issued a sober list of instructions to all members of the Home Guard telling them how to deal with anybody in this country who tries to stir up a riot.

LONDON, Sept. 18--There was little business in today's stock markets, but the undertone in most groups remained firm. Gilt-edge securities maintained their recent prices along with most industrials. Tobaccos found few buyers and textiles showed a tendency to harden toward the close. The little movement in oils and minings created several bright features in the Kaffirs.

TULSA, Sept. 18 (AP)--A merger which would put the Tide Water Associated Oil Company into the "Big Ten" of the oil industry was reported being discussed today. It was said the Skelly Oil Company and other oil and gas interests controlled by J. Paul Getty might be consolidated with Tide Water if a basis for official negotiations was found.

Mr. and Mrs. Jay Robinson Duff gave a dinner last night in the Perroquet Suite of the WaldorfAstoria for Miss Eileen Balfe and Mrs. Duff's son, Robert A. Glaenzer, whose marriage will take place this afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church.

THE gallant Henry de Montherlant is back with more exquisitely unflattering (and pro found) things to say about the female sex and more clinical notes on the fascinating and nowfamous case of Pierre Costals vs. poor Solange Dandillot. "Costals and the Hippogriff"* is the title of the story this time, and the hippogriff, of course, is the creature that lurks behind the fourth pew on the left-hand aisle of every Little Church Around the Corner.

Appointment of four "no third term" Democrats as State advisory chairmen to the national committee of Democrats-for-Willkie in Missouri, Oklahoma, Minnesota and Eastern Pennsylvania was announced here yesterday by Alan Valentine, executive director of the committee, at campaign headquarters, 122 East Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18--In the Federal court in New York City next week an important step toward control by Washington of intrastate, as well as interstate, passenger airline operation will be taken by the Civil Aeronautics Board. Though nothing in the act
The mechanics of the present Selective Training and Service Act and the steps by which a man becomes a trainee and finally a member of the nation's armed forces are discussed in these daily articles.

Replaced as Governor General of New Caledonia, a French island possession near Australia, by order of the Petain government, Marie Pelicier, his wife, Henriette, and son, Jean, 12 years old, left for Europe yesterday afternoon on the Lisbon-bound Atlantic Clipper of Pan American Airways. Nine

Joseph E. McWilliams was committed to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for ten days' examination as to his sanity, when he came before Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Harlem Court on his second conviction of disorderly conduct in connection with his self-proclaimed attempt to do in the United States what Hitler has done in Germany.
DETROIT, Sept. 18--For the second straight day the cellar-dwelling Athletics rose up to knock a team out of the American League lead.

Like a man on an icy pavement who starts slipping and just can't regain his balance, the Giants took another fall yesterday at the Polo Grounds when the Cubs beat them with two runs in the ninth for the tenth straight setback to the staggering New Yorkers. The score was 6 to 4.

Unnecessary absences in the city's schools are costing the Board of Education $2,000,000 annually in State grants, George H. Chatfield, director of the attendance bureau, declared yesterday. School principals and supervisors therefore were warned to treat the question of truancy much more seriously.

ROME, Sept. 18--Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany arrives in Rome at 12:50 tomorrow afternoon, it was announced here today. While the chief purpose of his visit is surrounded in secrecy, it is everywhere remarked that a new phase in the war and in European history is about to begin.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 18 (AP)-- Benjamin G. Slaughter, consulting engineer who supervised the construction of large industrial plants at Hopewell, Va., and Rome, Ga., died here today at his home after a heart attack. His age was 59.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18--All hope of maintaining a free economy in the world would be gone for a generation if this country entered the war, Herbert Hoover asserted tonight in an address at the University of Pennsylvania bicentennial conference. Totalitarian dic
Ameen Rihani, Syrian poet and leader, died Saturday in Freike, Mount Lebanon, Syria, of injuries suffered in a fall, according to word received here yesterday. He was 63 years old.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 18 (AP)-- George Washburn, lanky righthander who won eighteen games this season and will join the Yankees next Spring, tonight pitched the Newark Bears to a 3-1 victory over the Jersey City Giants to put his mates two games up in the preliminary round of the Governors' Cup series.

LONDON, Sept. 18--Sir Archibald Sinclair, Air Minister; Lord Woolton, Minister of Food, and Ernest Bevin; Minister of Labor--the three Cabinet members most immediately concerned with the current air battles--gave cheering words to the British nation today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 18--The Italian advance along the coastal road paused today at Sidi Barrani, where the invaders are consolidating their position. British bombers, meanwhile, raided almost continuously, starting at least ten fires in attacks on enemy transport. Gun emplacements at Sidi Barrani were destroyed.

The influence of weather upon war, often shown in the course of military history, was again demonstrated this week as the first of the equinoctial gales lashed the English Channel and encouraged the defenders of Britain.

VICHY, France, Sept. 18--In an endeavor to direct the resumption of industry and farm production in France toward reorganization in keeping with post-war possibilities the French Government has issued a series of new rulings affecting industry and labor.

Following closely on the heels of a suit by a Queens retailer against five distillers asking the court to invalidate fair-trade price contracts on liquor. Hearn's Department Store last night announced that it had entered the price war and issued advertisements for publication today

Don Meade aboard the favorite sent a good many in Aqueduct's crowd of 10,000 home happy yesterday as the Western lad was first on W. H. Berri's Early Delivery. It was an easy victory, by a fourlength margin, with a $4.90 for $2 pay-off at the end of the six-furlong Pegasus Purse. The betting ran to $600,280 on the seven races.

LONDON, Sept. 18--Londoners yawned their way from air-raid shelters and from under kitchen tables today after nearly ten hours of continuous alarm to find the German raiders had again bombed and set fire to places all over the metropolitan area. In the Oxford Street shopping district three big stores were damaged, one being virtually demolished.

Fur styles took a spirited turn yesterday afternoon at a showing held at Russeks. Four groups shown were created from a man's point of view. The argument that lay behind this idea is the age-old one that women dress for men.

Declaring that the management of industry does not have to be conscripted because it has already volunteered, H. W. Prentis Jr., president of the National Association of Manufacturers, disclosed last night a four-point program launched by the association "to clear the road for production in the drive for national defense."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 (AP)--Irving Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said today that materials needed for national defense will be produced quicker and at lower cost "if private enterprise is at the helm under its own leadership." In an address prepared at a luncheon opening a three-day inspection tour of United States steel plants by officials of the corporation, Mr. Olds said:

The prospect that the Berkshire Symphonic Festival will branch out into opera next Summer came closer to reality when it was learned last night that a theatre seating 1,200, would be built at Tanglewood, the festival grounds, next Spring.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY IN EGYPT, Sept. 18--Hustling along like a crosstown bus, two and possibly three divisions have come along the desert track from Bagbag to Sidi Barrani in a haze of white dust that has settled over Matruh, the Italians' next objective in Egypt.

The resumption of European refugee movement toward its colony in the Dominican Republic was announced here yesterday by the Dominican Republic Settlement Association, a $10,000,000 philanthropic corporation that grew out of the Evian Conference of 1938 with United States Government cooperation.

The State of Tennessee "is 100 per cent for conscription and will fill her quota, with volunteers," declared Prentice Cooper, Governor of Tennessee, at the World's Fair yesterday. Colonel Philip B. Fleming, WageHour Administrator, will sail for Puerto Rico today on the liner Coamo, heading a delegation of experts who will conduct hearings on wages and working conditions in the needlework industry of Puerto Rico. Accompanying him
Total admitted assets of the Home Insurance Company, New York, increased to $114,161,033 on June 30 from $112,869,753 a year earlier, according to the semi-annual statement issued yesterday.

A thousand men and one girl have been accepted as entering freshmen at City College and will attend their first classes today at the main center of the college, 139th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. A total of 22,500 students will return to their classes, opening the college's ninetyfourth academic year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP)-- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that when, and if, married men were drafted for military service. her four sons should be called in preference to men whose families were entirely dependent upon them for support.

Contributions from pharmaceutical houses, hospitals and doctors, as well as from Miss Helen Keller and Cecil de Mille, to the Medical and Surgical Supply Committee, 420 Lexington Avenue, to provide relief shipments to England were announced yesterday by Mrs. Millicent

Plans for modernizing a property in Greenwich Village were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by Lach Operators, Inc., of the three four-story tenements at the southeast corner of Charles and Greenwich Streets.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18--Old Johnny Allen and youthful Bob Feller threw a spell over the Washington Senators today. The Cleveland Indians thus swept a double-header and drove back into first place ahead of the Detroit Tigers.

The $250,000 Japanese Pavilion at the World's Fair became yesterday the property of the City of New York and the first building at the exposition to be formally made a part of the oposed Flushing Meadow Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18--Details of the 3,000-word report by the National Defense Commission to Attorney General Jackson on the proposed anti-monopoly suit to disintegrate the activities of twenty-two large oil companies and their subsidiaries were made public today by the Attorney General on his return from Alabama.
Rentals with four new tenants in the El Dorado at 300 Central Park West were announced yesterday by E. Eugene Grossman, representing the owners. The latest lessees are

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (AP)--Miss Bertha Baur, president emeritus of the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music, died here today. Miss Baur, who was born in Ann Arbor, Mich., was named conservatory director in 1912.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18--Buying of wheat futures, which brokers attributed to mills and cash interests, combined with firmness in securities, resulted today in an advance of about 1 cent a bushel. While profit-taking developed on the upturn the close on the Board of Trade here was close to the top, with gains of 3/8 to 1 cent, the latter on the May.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18--Thirtyfour out of fifty Washington correspondents choose President Roosevelt to win, and sixteen chose Wendell L. Willkie. The poll was taken for the Periscope Review of News Week. The average forecast was that Roosevelt would receive 312 electoral votes and Willkie 219.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18-- Yale's scant line material was further depleted today when X-rays disclosed that Frank Kemp of Denver, who had been picked for firststring tackle, had broken his wrist during the contact work yesterday and will be unable to play until late in the season, if at all.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 18-- Dr. George W. Goler died today at Strong Memorial Hospital, where he had been a patient for some time. He was 76 years old and had devoted his medical career to the cause of child health and hygiene.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 19-- Six French warships that recently were allowed through the Strait of Gibraltar without molestation by British guns are now at Dakar, French naval base on the west coast of Africa, it was stated in London this morning. Before the ships

CHICAGO, Sept. 18--They were all set to bury the Yankees without honors today when, with the raucous taunts of 37,331 gloating Chicagoans dinning in their ears, the fading world champions literally lifted themselves by their boot straps to beat the White Sox in the second game of a double-header, 9 to 8, after tossing off the first, 6 to 3.

Two young men armed with pistols and a knife held up the office of the Our Darling Sportswear Company, on the third floor of the building at 50 Bond Street, early yesterday afternoon, locked five persons in a washroom and escaped with $488.

WESTBURY, I.I., Sept. 18-Great Neck rode into the final of polo's high-goal handicap championship tournament today when it turned back Texas, 9 to 6, in the first semi-final for the Monty Waterbury Cup. On Sunda Great Neck is to meet the winner of tomorrow's match between Aknusti and Gulf Stream.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 18-- Over the Lakeville Club's course, her home links, Mrs. R.M. Torgerson today scored a 78, one under women's par, to lead the competitors in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament. Her total was only two strokes higher than the best round she has ever had at Lakeville.

FORT DIX N.J., Sept. 18-- Young men still in civilian clothes and older A. E. F. fighters, who are now buddies in the Forty-fourth Division, motor-marched into Fort Dix today to begin a year of field service under the emergency mobilization program intended to give the United States a first-class Army to stand by during troubled times.

THE NEW YORK TIMES supported Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Presidency in 1932 and again in 1936. In 1940 it will support Wendell Willkie.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 18--A German sea raider refueled and took on other supplies at Kobe, Japan, and cleared that port, with her guns visible, on Sept. 13, this correspondent has learned from a reliable authority.

Wendell L. Willkie was described yesterday as "emotionally unstable" by Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. The Republican nominee was also accused during a press conference at committee headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore of "trying to camouflage the issues by talking about dictatorship."

The Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians has leased the Adelphi Theatre at 152 West Fiftyfourth Street for three years at an aggregate rental of $75,000 in a deal which gives the group an option to purchase the property at $400,000.

PEARL RIVER, N.Y., Sept. 18-- The Giants staged a two-hour scrimmage at the Blue Hill C. C. today as Coach Steve Owen attempted to correct the ragged play of the Eastern champions before they tackle the Redskins Sunday in Washington.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18--Cincinnati won its second straight National League championship today by coming from behind to beat the Phillies, 4 to 3, in a thirteen-inning battle.

Kammer Sr. of Baltusrol, runner-up last year, forged into the lead today in the annual New Jersey State seniors' golf championship and will be declared the titleholder tomorrow night unless Benjamin Y. Patterson of Spring Lake scores an 80 or better tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19--With the steel industry operating near the limit of its producing capacity and demand still rising it may be necessary to establish some system of priorities on steel orders, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--Reporting rapid progress on several phases of the nation's defense program, Secretary Stimson said today that contracts had been let for almost half of the 18,641 Army planes for which Congress appropriated funds at this session.

"Cabin in the Sky," the Negro musical formerly known as "Little Joe," is announced to open Oct. 21 at the Martin Beck. A tryout engagement in Boston has been abandoned in favor of a series of previews the week of Oct. 14. Albert Lewis is the producer.

The flat sea that has been annoying the surf casters has been a boon to the men who have been engaged in off-shore chumming for tuna, and several of the Freeport, Bay Shore and Babylon boats have been returning with from five to ten tuna, ranging up to 150 pounds in weight.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 19--Secretaries Hull and Ickes replied today to the speech made yesterday at Phoenix, Ariz., by Wendell L. Willkie. Each of the Cabinet members devoted himself to different parts of the Republican's speech.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 19--The Egyptian Cabinet finally met today to discuss the present situation and he stand that the country now must take in view of the Italian invasion.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24-- After nearly two weeks of hard work the Harvard football coaches announced today the squad had suffered the first serious injury. Johnny Page, last year's center, who was making such fine progress in the middle of the varsity line, is out for the season.
TOKYO, Sept. 24--Declaring Christianity radically contrary to Japan's guiding spirit, a meeting of patriotic societies Saturday organized the Federation to Campaign Against Christian Organizations.

There are several questions the salt-water angler would like to have answered. Some he directs to other anglers, some to the United States Bureau of Fisheries and still others to the State Conservation Department. Except for feelers put out on matters of angling methods and practices, the answers are slow in arriving and not too complete when they arrive.

Largely because of the national defense program and the import tax of 4 cents a pound, the domestic market for copper is rising on an increased volume of business while the world price is steadily declining.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,621,050 barrels, a decline of 26,350 from the 3,647,400 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The deadlock in the strike of 12,000 painters, now in its fifth week, persisted yesterday as the Association of Master Painters, the employers' organization, again failed to take definite action on Mayor La Guardia's proposal for settlement of the strike.

Arturo Toscanini's first concert of the season with the NBC Symphony Orchestra will be given as a tribute to the late Alma Gluck, American soprano and wife of Efrem Zimbalist, the violinist. She died two years ago.

LONDON, Sept. 24--The British people, having plenty of spare time on their hands these evenings, are using it, the British people always do, in writing letters to the editor. At present they are engaged in a controversy over whether or not to pray for their enemies.

Clark Chauncey Foster of 12 Huguenot Drive, Larchmont, N.Y., and 601 West 115th Street, this city, a pioneer in the operation of 5-and10-cent stores, died yesterday in his town apartment after a brief illness. His age was 87.

The Protestant Episcopal Church is the United States will give substantial financial assistance to the mother church in England for the first time if a recommendation of its national council is adopted by the denomination's general convention to be held in Kansas City, Oct. 9 to 24.

The return on investments last year accruing to life insurance companies, as a result of generally reduced interest rates, was about $400,000,000 lower than would have been the case had the average interest rate for the ten years preceding the depression prevailed, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24--Defense program contracts of more than $21,000,000 were announced today by the War and Navy Departments.

The decline in enrolment in the New York City school system is continuing, the net loss for this term being 37,319 pupils, the greatest drop for any single year in its history, a preliminary report on registration disclosed yesterday.

Lou Salica, veteran campaigner from the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, became the bantamweight champion of the world for the second time in his career when he defeated Georgie Pace of Cleveland in a fifteen-round bout at the Bronx Coliseum last night.

Dissension in the American Guild of Variety Artists, which was formed a year ago to replace Ralph Whitehead's American Federation of Actors as the A.F. of L. affiliate covering vaudeville, circuses and cabarets, came to a head early yesterday morning at a meeting of the union's New York local in the Hotel Edison.

Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, charged yesterday that Wendell L. Wilikie was deceiving the unemployed of the country by promising them jobs that he could not provide if elected.

Van Valkenburgh, assistant New York State health commissioner, said here today that preparation should get under way now for the care of the health of the civilian population of New York City in case of attack and evacuation, and recommended that a public health representative be included "at once" in the national and State defense councils.

DETROIT, Oct. 1--Members of the National Federation of Wo men's Republican Clubs adjourned their first convention this afternoon in the Masonic Temple here following election of Mrs. Charles W. Weis Jr. of Rochester as president of the two-year-old organization.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 1--It is the eve of another world series, baseball's offering as the greatest show on earth. Folks are hustling and scurrying in all directions. Some are still futilely looking for tickets which vanished from view weeks ago. Others, even more frantically, are stamping up and down hotel lobbies in quest of even the most humble cots upon which to rest their weary frames tonight.

Major Garland Williams, Federal narcotic supervisor in the New York area for the last four years, assumed his new duties yesterday as district coordinator of six Treasury departments and pledged an intensification of efforts to guard against sabotage, to locate Fifth Columnists and to push the national preparedness program.
VICHY, France, Oct. 1--In a communique published after a ministerial council tonight, it is stated that the discussion of the Cabinet turned on fixing a definite status for Jews in France.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago, as everybody knows, Somerset Maugham wrote a great novel called "Of Human Bondage." Some readers may be astonished to learn that the publishers of Hans Otto Storm's latest novel, "Count Ten," compare it to "Of Human Bondage."

LONDON, Oct. 1 (UP)--Great Britain announced today its highest week's shipping losses of the war --131,857 tons, or more than the weekly average of British shipping sunk in April, 1917, at the peak of unrestricted submarine warfare in the last war.

The stock market adopted yesterday a more realistic attitude toward the news of the day, and, in broader and heavier trading, values were restored to their mid-May levels with prices increased 1 to 3 points.

VICHY, France, Oct. 1--Two more "administrative internments" were announced this evening simultaneously with a communique issued after a Cabinet meeting. The persons involved are Charles Pomaret and Charles Montel. They have been taken to Pellevoisin, which is now styled "house of detention No. 2."

LONDON, Oct. 1--Sir Robert Abbott Hadfield, world-famous metallurgist, the inventor of manganese and silicon steel and many other alloy steels and metallurgical improvements, died here last night at the age of 81.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--More than any other member of this administration Secretary of the Interior Ickes has given the impression of a man concerned only with the present and the future. Armed with rapier, broadsword, bludgeon and bladder, he has mixed with all comers on current questions.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 1 (AP)-- Asserting that the Middle West was for President Roosevelt, Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that Wendell L. Willkie thus far "has raised no real issue" in the Presidential campaign.

LONDON, Oct. 1--The German invasion bases were bombed by the Royal Air Force again tonight, according to residents on the southeast coast, who said they heard the rumble of distant explosions and saw flashes resembling sheet lightning, as of exploding bombs, around Boulogne and along Cap Gris Nez, where long-range guns are concealed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--President Roosevelt denounced today as reprehensible the actions of some persons in Michigan in throwing missiles at the Willkie party.

FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 1--The mobilized citizen-soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division began to drill today in fields lush with clover, wildflowers and, in some places, knee-high weeds that virtually hid manoeuvring feet from the critical eyes of instructing officers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--An increase of nearly $2,400,000,000 in the income of the people of the United States in the first eight months of this year over the comparable period in 1939 was announced today by Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce.

LONDON, Oct. 1--With Winter approaching and Nazi air raids continuing, the government today enlisted the directive genius of Admiral Sir Edward R.G.R. Evans --"Evans of the Broke"--to solve the urgent problem of providing warm and adequate shelter for all of London's people.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--A third term for President Roosevelt, in this time of world crisis, was urged today by Dean Acheson, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, in a letter which will be printed in The Baltimore Sun tomorrow.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,799,950 barrels, an increase of 178,900 over the 3,621,050 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

In preparing to draft men into the Army the government has attempted to avoid mistakes made here and in other countries both during the World War and in the present war, particularly as regards the granting of deferment because of occupation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--President Roosevelt today told a military group representing many of the other republics in the Western Hemisphere that the American defense program was a matter of "one for all and all for one." The visitors in their turn assured the President that their countries were pledged to support a continuance of American ideals.

Willkie sentiment in Nebraska took a sharp rise even before the Republican Presidential candidate entered that State last week to make his farm speech at Omaha, and Nebraska is still leaning Republican by a substantial margin, the latest survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion reveals, according to its director, Dr. George Gallup.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP)-- Smashing power at the plate versus an air-tight defense may be the theme of the little world series which gets under way here tomorrow night between the slugging Newark Bears of the International League and the close-fielding Louisville Colonels of the American Association.

BERLIN, Oct. 1--As the German Air Force day by day carries out its routine raids against Britain, notably her capital, it is becoming apparent from statements made by authoritative quarters in Berlin that the main objective now is to harass and wear down British nerves and British economy and, finally, British military strength.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1--Winthrop Rockefeller, grandson of the late John D., and junior assistant of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., recommended learning "the dignity of labor" as a way to good citizenship at the twenty-fifth National Recreation Congress tonight.
When the fifty American destroyers transferred to Britain go on patrol, forty-nine of them will bear names common to the United Kingdom and the United States or to the United States and Canada.
Furs, particularly neckwear, are likely to figure as one of the major gift items during the coming Christmas pjeriod, well-known merchandisers here predicted yesterday.
Mary Hill Doolittle, 'cellist, will give a recital at 8:30 o'clock tonight at Town Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2--Gene Davis of suburban Narberth will call signals and do the blockingback chores for Pennsylvania in the Franklin Field opener Saturday with Maryland.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 2-- William Lee Stoddart of this village, a New York architect specializing in the design of hotels, banks and postoffices, died yesterday in the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital after suffering a stroke earlier in the day. His age was 71.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2--Military authorities, after underlining that yesterday's events in Monterrey had only slight repercussions throughout the country, stated they have the situation under complete control.
MADRID, Oct. 2--Dispatches from Rome published in some Madrid papers today give the most definite indication thus far that Spain does not plan to enter the war immediately.

Wendell L. Willkie will make speeches in Union Square and the Garment Center in the course of a tour of Manhattan next Tuesday, it became known here yesterday. All the various Willkie headquarters worked at top speed preparing a schedule for the candidate in the metropolitan area and New England.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--An assertion that Solicitor General Francis Biddle abused his official position on two occasions, once as counsel for the TVA Investigating Committee and again as Solicitor General, in attempting to "injure and destroy" a newspaper whose only afternoon rival was a paper in which he was financially interested, was made in the Senate today by Senator Bridges of New Hampshire.

A tightening up of deliveries on desirable goods in the men's clothing and furnishings field, partly as the result of improved business and partly beeause of defense orders, developed this week, manufacturers and buyers reported yasterday.

As the Republican-controlled State House Commission of New Jersey went ahead yesterday with the plan to force the installation of voting machines in Hudson Coputy it became known that the 1936 and 1937 poll books had been destroyed in other Hague strongholds besides Jersey City.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP)--The Chicago Cubs, behind a seven-hit pitching performance by Rookie Vern Olsen and some wobbly defensive work by their American League opponents, defeated the White Sox by 8 to 2 today to square the city championship series at one victory apiece.

Actors, singers and announcers on network sustaining programs are to receive pay increases under the terms of a tentative agreement reached yesterday by representatives of the American Federation of Radio Artists and the three major broadcasting chains.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--A new United States naval force will be established in the Atlantic in the near future, according to a Navy Department announcement tonight.
Contests will play a prominent part for the first time in the 1941 advertising campaign of the Goodall Company for its Palm Beach and tropic weight suit.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 2--Blasting three Louisville pitchers for fifteen hits behind the six-hit hurling of lanky George Washburn, Newark won the first game of the Little World Series tonight, 10 to 3.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 2 (AP)--Howard Bruce's Jay Jay won his second Capital Handicap today in a drive that saw him finish a half-length in front of W.L. Brann's Pictor, with J.E. Widener's Roman third. Showing a liking for a muddy track, the veteran son of Wise Counsellor and Dry Girl withstood a long drive and brought his backers a $12.30 mutuel.

Three members of the Painters and Decorators Union were arraigned in court yesterday and a fourth was named in an indictment for smearing paint on the front of an apartment house, as District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey announced that vandalism and assaults in strikes "will not be tolerated in this county."

LONDON, Oct. 2-- The British Government announced today that it would rather assume responsibility for keeping children here, despite the nightly indiscriminate bombing raids, than subject them to the perils of a stormy crossing of the North Atlantic now that Germany has again resorted to unrestrained submarine warfare.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., Oct. 2--Despite the efforts made by the government to improve farm prices, agriculture is still far from parity with industry, according to a resolution adopted here today at the closing session of the annual National Catholic Rural Life Conference.

They're turning on the lights in Ebbets Field tonight--not for a baseball game or a gridiron battle, but for Coach Jock Sutherland to give his football Dodgers an idea of how things will look under artificial daylight when they tangle with the Philadelphia Eagles tomorrow evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--Representatives of twelve international broadcast stations will meet here Monday at the invitation of the Federal Communications Commission to discuss with its international division rules for the broadcasting of programs to foreign countries.

The City Planning Commission established yesterday a "Times Square district" in which advertising signs of all kinds and sizes, including spectacular flashing electrical displays, may be installed and used free from the drastic restrictions contained in the building zone resolution adopted by the commission and approved by the Board of Estimate last Summer.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 2-- Drenching rain all day on the beautiful show grounds of the Piping Rock Club curtailed the attendance at the opening program of the thirty-eighth Piping Rock horse show.

BERLIN, Oct. 2--A new and permanent agreement regulating railroad traffic between Soviet Russia and Germany went into effect yesterday, it was revealed here today. The agreement was signed Monday following negotiations in Berlin between Dr. Holtz, president of the German State Railways, and Mr. Nisoveuff, Russian director of international traffic.

LONDON, Oct. 2--Royal Air Force bombers swarmed far and wide over Germany and German-occupied territories again this morning and last night, fulfilling their twofold task of smashing war factories and communication lines and doing their utmost to prevent Nazi ground troops from sailing from the Channel ports in an attempt to invade Britain.

Now that the blow has fallen and the watershed fishing permits have been canceled, pending the formation of new rules and regulations, the anglers hardly know where they stand. Some favor the belief that they will be eased out with as little fuss as possible and others are a bit more optimistic.

Miss Sarah Palfrey of Brookline, Mass., America's third ranking woman tennis player, and Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., sixth ranking American player, were married yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 2--Surprisingly enough, there was little excitement in the clubhouse today after the Tigers' crushing conquest of the Reds in the first game of the world series.
VICHY, France, Oct. 2--Vice Premier Pierre Laval's newspaper the Clermont-Ferrand Moniteur, yesterday condemned "mendacious rumors" and "Hypocritical propaganda."

ROME, Oct. 2--Pope Pius XII tonight was reported to be preparing an encyclical warning Catholics throughout the world to be on guard against "communistic influences" resulting from the international struggle to win Russia's support.

Three disorderly attacks have been made on the headquarters of the Woodhaven Willkie Club at 93-45 Jamaica Avenue, Woodhaven, Queens, it became known last night. During the early evening while the club was closed two large plate glass show windows, in which posters of Wendell L. Willkie had been displayed, were smeared with mud in the latest attack.

Orders and reorders in most of the wholesale markets here continued quite heavy this week and reports from accounts throughout the country on retail trade have continued favorable, resident buyers reported yesterday.

More Wall Street banks announced yesterday statements of condition, as of Sept. 30. In most cases these reports showed deposits and total resources at record levels. On the basis of the statements of condition released thus far, the trend has been toward moderate increases in loans and discounts.

Two invasion alarms that brought the British "Army and Navy springing to their stations" have actually been sounded along the English Channel coast within the last six weeks, according to Vincent Sheean, author and foreign correspondent, who arrived here yesterday aboard the Atlantic Clipper from Lisbon.

LONDON, Oct. 2--Decrying rumors that famine faces Europe this Winter, Hugh Dalton, Minister of Economic Warfare, at a luncheon in his honor today predicted that the blockade would bring Adolf Hitler's Reich to its knees as twenty-two years ago the Allied blockade caused the collapse of the former Kaiser's Germany.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 2--An assault on Paul Derringer for five hits and five runs in the second inning proved to be more than enough to settle the outcome of the first game of the world series today. The Tigers piled up a total of ten hits, while the Reds were making eight off the pitching of Buck Newsom. No more than two Cincinnati hits came in any one inning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The combined volume of business of five listed corporations engaged primarily in producing distilled beverages and having assets of more than $10,000,000 each was $308,000,000 in 1939, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2--Balked by its organization policy from taking action in protest against a recommendation by the Federal Bureau of the Budget that naturalist programs in the national parks be discontinued, delegates to the National Recreation Congress registered today unanimous opposition to the move.

The new producing firm of W. Horace Schmidlapp and Joseph M. Gaites has decided to bring "Boyd's Shop," St. John Greer Ervine's first new play here since "The First Mrs. Fraser" (1929), to the Booth on Oct. 15.

VICHY, France, Oct. 2--While the French Government is engaged in the preparation of a permanent project to fix the status of Jews in unoccupied France, an ordinance was announced in Paris today fixing certain regulations for the Jewish population in the occupied territory. BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 2--Freelan O. Stanley, who with his twin brother, the late Francis Stanley, invented the Stanley Steamer, which appeared in the late Nineties in competition with the early gasolinedriven motor cars, died tonight in his home at Newton. His age was 91. He had returned ten days ago from Colorado, where he spent the Summer.
